The lioness has a GPS collar fitted by Kope Lion, a conservation NGO, which has been monitoring her movements and behavior. Dr Luke Hunter, President and Chief Conservation Officer for Panthera, a global wild cat conservation organisation which supports Kope Lion, told the BBC the incident was "truly unique". "It's not something that I'm aware has ever happened before between large cats like this," he said. "We know there are cases where lionesses will adopt other lion cubs, but this is unprecedented. As the prime minister sat down with US President Barack Obama at the White House, a weighty issue hung in the air. In 2011, a senior judge reviewing the treaty found it to be fair to British citizens, and it's hard to ignore the fact that some of the most high-profile cases involving British citizens have ultimately been resolved without too much fuss. Still, the issue remains a contentious one, and it's little surprise that Prime Minister Cameron chose to raise it during his talks with Obama. The original Suez Canal opened almost 150 years ago and links the Mediterranean with the Red Sea, allowing ships to travel between Europe and Asia without having to navigate around Africa. Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi says the expansion of one of the world's busiest shipping routes will boost trade and increase employment across the country. It currently handles 7% of global sea-borne business, and is one of the most important waterways in the world. With this expansion, Egypt hopes to increase its share of global trade and become a major player in international commerce.

Leeds Crown Court heard that James Carragher, a man with a dark history, was jailed for seven years in 1993 and 14 years in 2004 for sex offences. But now, he's facing new allegations, denying 50 counts of indecent assault that took place between the 1970s and the 1990s at St William's in Market Weighton, East Riding of Yorkshire. This is not the first time Carragher has been accused of such crimes; two other former staff members at the home also went on trial earlier for their alleged involvement in the abuse. The home, which was run by the Catholic De La Salle order, was a facility for boys with behavioral problems, and it's since been closed. According to prosecutors, Carragher, who was the head of St William's from 1976 to 1990, and two other men are accused of abusing 19 former pupils between them. As the prosecution's case unfolds, it's clear that Carragher was a man who had a "committed sexual interest in children and young boys in particular". Richard Wright QC, the prosecutor, emphasized that Carragher "hid behind a cloak of respectability", making it seem impossible that anyone would believe the allegations against him. But as the truth begins to unravel, it's clear that Carragher's actions were far from respectable.

Long-time Mugabe critic Morgan Tsvangirai and former Vice-President Joice Mujuru have announced that they will be working together in next year's election, in a significant development that may pose a unified challenge to the ruling Zanu-PF party. However, it remains unclear which of the two leaders will ultimately be the presidential candidate. Mr. Mugabe, now 93 years old, has been in power since Zimbabwe gained independence from Britain in 1980 and has indicated his intention to seek re-election. In a statement, Mr. Tsvangirai described the alliance as "just the beginning of the building blocks towards establishing a broad alliance to confront Zanu-PF between now and the next election." The collaboration is a crucial first step towards uniting a deeply divided opposition, which has long been fractured and lacking a unified front. If this alliance is successful, it would be the first time President Mugabe has faced a united opposition on this scale since taking power in 1980. At least a decade ago, the opposition was still in disarray, with various factions and parties vying for influence and power.

During the meeting, Mr. Juncker reiterated his commitment to democratic expressions, stating that he would respect the outcome of the Scottish independence referendum, which is scheduled to take place in September. When asked about the possibility of Catalonia and Scotland joining the EU, he emphasized that membership in the European Union cannot be achieved through a simple letter or declaration.

Community leaders from Santa Clara County filed a notice of intention on Monday to collect signatures to recall Judge Aaron Persky next year. Judge Persky was accused of leniency in his June 2016 punishment of Stanford University swimmer Brock Turner, a decision that sent shockwaves through the nation. Turner had faced up to 14 years in prison for the January 2015 assault, but was handed a six-month sentence, and was released after serving only three months in county jail. The lenient sentence sparked widespread outrage, with many critics arguing that it perpetuated a culture of impunity for sexual predators. "Judge Aaron Persky stunned the world when he sentenced Stanford swimmer Brock Turner to six months in jail for sexually assaulting an unconscious woman behind a dumpster at a fraternity party," the notice to circulate a recall petition states. Stanford law professor Michele Dauber, who is leading the recall effort along with 50 community leaders, said at a news conference: "Santa Clara County residents deserve a judge who will protect victims, not rapists. They deserve a judge who will take their claims of sexual assault seriously, and who will hold perpetrators accountable for their crimes. Women have had enough of rape culture," she added. "We are ready to take action and ensure that our justice system reflects the values of fairness, compassion, and justice for all. It's time for Judge Persky to go, and for a new era of accountability and respect for victims to begin."

Entrants to the annual event have five minutes to tell the biggest and most convincing lie they can, showcasing their creativity and storytelling skills. Winner George Kemp from Maryport, Cumbria was surprised to win as he was "struggling" with a chest infection, which added an extra layer of challenge to his already impressive tale. In his story, he claimed to have "ended up bumping into Donald Trump and his wife in an underwater hotel", where he revealed a remarkable invention - a small submarine built from his dad's old bubble car. Kemp explained that the bubble car was taken on a trip to the Isle of Man, where they encountered several famous people in a Scottish submarine made out of shortbread tins. He recounted that Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond, the Scottish First Minister and former First Minister respectively, had sold some of these giant shortbread tin submarines to the United States of America. The judges were impressed by Kemp's vivid storytelling and imaginative scenario, awarding him the top prize. Last year's winner, Mike Naylor, known as Monkey Liar, from Wasdale came second, followed closely by Helen Jordan in third place. Previous winners of the competition include comedian and television presenter Sue Perkins, who has used her experience to entertain audiences with her unique blend of humor and storytelling.

Ms Huws said she hoped her report was the "beginning of the end" for patients being unable to have healthcare "appropriate to their needs". You see, it's a bit of a problem when you can't communicate with your doctor or healthcare provider in the language you're most comfortable with. It's like trying to order a meal in a restaurant where you don't speak the language - it's just not the same. And that's exactly what's happening to many Welsh speakers in Wales. It's hard to argue with that kind of overwhelming support.

The bill, a deliberate attempt to unravel the tangled threads of the UK government's 2016 Trade Union Act, seeks to liberate parts of the act from its shackles. Should it pass, the restrictive measures currently suffocating industrial action in the NHS, fire service, schools, and other devolved services in Wales would be released from their straitjacket. The UK government's stalwart position, that industrial relations are a matter for Westminster, is met with skepticism by the Welsh Assembly's Equality, Local Government and Communities Committee, which insists that maintaining Wales' "social-partnership" approach requires a more nuanced approach. A key provision of the UK government's law, which stipulates that strikes must be backed by at least 40% of a union's members in a ballot, is particularly galling to the committee, which believes it stifles the democratic process. In March, Welsh Finance Secretary Mark Drakeford issued a dire warning, cautioning that it would be a "democratic outrage" if ministers in London attempted to block the Welsh Trade Union Bill, which seeks to give Welsh unions the autonomy to organize and negotiate in their own right. The Labour Welsh Government, in tandem with the committee, argues that UK ministers should not impose restrictions on union activity in Wales in devolved services, such as the NHS and schools, where the very fabric of Welsh society is woven.

Evha Jannath, a 11-year-old student, met a tragic end on Tuesday when she fell from a circular boat on the Splash Canyon ride at Drayton Manor, a theme park in Staffordshire. The incident has sent shockwaves through the entertainment industry, prompting several amusement parks to take precautions and temporarily close similar water-based thrill rides. Among those to have taken this measure are Alton Towers and Legoland Windsor, two popular attractions also owned by Merlin Entertainments, the parent company of Drayton Manor. In a statement, Drayton Manor announced that it would remain closed on Friday to facilitate health and safety investigations into the incident. Meanwhile, Merlin Entertainments, in a cautious move, shut down the affected rides "with immediate effect" as a precautionary measure, stating that it expected to reopen them on Friday. Not all theme parks have followed suit, however, with some, such as Lightwater Valley in North Yorkshire and West Midland Safari Park, choosing not to close their water-based rides in response to the fatality at Drayton Manor.

Construction workers, who had long been required to hold a CSCS card to prove their skills and understanding of health and safety, were found to be able to obtain these coveted cards through underhanded means. The joint BBC London/Newsnight investigation uncovered a network of test centres that were brazenly offering guaranteed passes for cash, effectively allowing workers who lacked even a basic understanding of English to obtain qualifications and gain access to potentially dangerous construction sites. The scheme, which was supposed to ensure that only qualified workers entered the construction industry, had been compromised by a web of deceit and corruption.The Construction Industry Training Board (CITB), one of the test providers, was forced to re-examine the qualifications of over 6,000 card-holders, a staggering number that highlights the extent of the problem. The CSCS cards, widely regarded as the UK's flagship scheme for certifying builders, had been rendered meaningless by the discovery of these corrupt test centres. The investigation shone a light on the dark underbelly of the construction industry, exposing centres that were willing to compromise the safety of workers and the integrity of the certification process in exchange for a quick profit.

The Air Accidents Investigation Branch (AAIB) report's findings are riddled with contradictions and unanswered questions. While it claims that cockpit footage shows the plane "responding to the pilot's control inputs", it also states that it's unclear whether pilot Andy Hill initiated his ejection. This lack of clarity raises serious concerns about the pilot's involvement in the crash and whether he may have been able to prevent it. The AAIB's report also reveals that the Hawker Hunter's canopy was released at the initial impact, releasing fuel and fuel vapour which then ignited. This sequence of events is eerily similar to a catastrophic chain reaction, but the report fails to provide a clear explanation for the ignition of the fuel. The report's conclusion that the jet split into four parts and both Mr. Hill and his seat were thrown clear of the cockpit raises more questions than answers. Was the pilot's seat ejected as a result of impact damage or did he intentionally initiate ejection? The investigation's inability to determine the cause of the ejection is a major failing, and it's unclear what further evidence or analysis is needed to resolve this critical question.

The IAAF World Half Marathon Championships are set to take place on Saturday, 26 March, in Cardiff, Wales. The event will attract around 200 of the world's top athletes and up to 25,000 amateur runners, who will compete over a 13.1-mile course. The route begins outside Cardiff Castle and finishes on King Edward VII Avenue in the city centre. According to Dave Bedford, a former 10,000m world record holder, the course is "flat" and showcases the best of Cardiff, highlighting both the city's historic and modern attractions. The route passes notable landmarks such as the Millennium Stadium, Cardiff City Stadium, Penarth Marina, the Cardiff Bay Barrage, the Wales Millennium Centre, and Roath Park Lake, before culminating in a grandstand finish in the heart of the city. The 2016 championships mark the first time the event has been held in Wales, and it is anticipated that the World Half Marathon will further enhance Cardiff's reputation as a major racing hub, particularly with double Olympic gold medallist double Olympic gold medallist.

An area of land stretching from Bo'ness Harbour to the former Kinneil colliery is poised to undergo a transformation, as it is designated as a haven for wildlife and plants, thereby becoming the second Local Nature Reserve created in the Falkirk Council area. This development marks a significant turning point for the site, which, for almost 200 years, was utilised for heavy industry, with the central colliery closing its doors in 1983. The attainment of reserve status signifies the culmination of a process that has been underway for some time, as parts of the area had already been recognised for their environmental importance. Specifically, the mudflats and "island" off the foreshore have been designated as a Special Protection Area (SPA) due to their conservation value. Councillor Adrian Mahoney, convener of leisure, tourism, and community, welcomed the new status for the Kinneil foreshore, observing that it coincides with a significant milestone in the area's history, namely the 30th anniversary of the closure of Kinneil Colliery, the last pit in the area.

Spencer Flower, a 72-year-old Conservative councillor from Verwood, Dorset, has been found guilty of voting illegally in a 2013 debate over the future of housing in east Dorset. The controversy surrounding his involvement with a social housing company, which could have potentially benefited from the plan being passed, has led to his conviction. Despite the breach of the Localism Act 2011, the district judge at Bournemouth Magistrates' Court has allowed Flower to remain in public office. In addition to the conditional discharge, Flower was ordered to pay £930 in costs.In a statement outside the courtroom, Flower expressed his surprise and disappointment at the court's decision, describing it as a "technicality". He emphasized that the court had recognized the lack of any personal gain or intent on his part, and noted that the six-month conditional discharge was the lowest possible penalty. When asked about his political future, Flower declined to comment, choosing to focus on the legal proceedings rather than his prospects in office.

The notable British vocalist, Black, who passed away in 2015, enjoyed a significant level of success in the 1960s, with one of her most notable achievements being a UK top 10 hit in 1964 with "It's for You", a song penned by none other than Paul McCartney and John Lennon. Interestingly, McCartney had recorded his own version of the song earlier that year, which was subsequently delivered to Black while she was performing at the renowned London Palladium. Despite its significance, it was believed that the disc had been lost or destroyed, until it was rediscovered by Black's nephew. This rare recording fetched a substantial £18,000 at the Beatles Memorabilia Auction, held at the Unity Theatre in Liverpool. However, it is worth noting that the final sale price to the unknown buyer, inclusive of commission, will amount to £21,060. Simon White, the auctioneer, expressed confidence that the sale would be a significant addition to the buyer's collection, given the song's historical significance and the unique circumstances surrounding its rediscovery.

Envoy Sigrid Kaag's voice was laced with urgency as she spoke on a tense Sunday, as Syria teetered on the brink of missing a crucial deadline to remove its chemical arsenal from the country. The weight of the task ahead hung in the balance, as the deadline to destroy all of Syria's chemical weapons loomed large, set for June 30th. It was a promise made last year, after the devastating sarin rocket attack outside Damascus, which claimed the lives of hundreds of innocent people. The multinational mission to rid Syria of its toxic stockpile was being overseen by the United Nations Security Council and the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), with the goal of eradicating the threat posed by these deadly weapons. Although the UN had set a June 30th deadline for the complete destruction of Syria's chemical weapons, Damascus had previously vowed to complete the removal of its stockpile by April 27th, a promise it had yet to fulfill. As Ms. Kaag, the head of the OPCW-UN mission, emphasized, a significant portion of the chemical weapons material had indeed been removed, but the remaining bulk was yet to be destroyed, and this counted towards the overall deadline. It was a delicate balancing act, with the fate of Syria's chemical weapons hanging precariously in the balance.
